S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:
> With all due respect, the signing/court issue is a
> red-herring.

It isn't a red-herring. It is a separate issue. Someone asked a question 
about it and we answered it!

> ...
> I can also link to a printable version of my
> unbilled transactions:
> 
>   https://www.accountonline.com/UnbilledTrans?PRINT_VERSION=Y
> 
> Both printable versions are simply current records
> of my account state without any links/buttons to
> make changes.
> 
> I'd like to be able to provide third parties
> (e.g. my accountant) with access to these pages,
> but I can't without providing them with control
> over my entire account.
> 
> The questions are:
> 1. Is this system RESTful?
> 2. Would it be RESTful if it used HTTP-auth rather than cookie auth?

1. Yes, it is RESTful, but it is lacking a feature that would be useful 
to you. It would be easy to extend the system with the feature you ask 
for. There could be a button that says: "universal link".

Conversely, if there was _only_ the universal link then your accountant 
could not send you a URI and say: "Click this to see your unbilled 
transactions."

But it is hard to imagine how this would work from a UI point of view. 
There are serious security implications. Would a typical user understand 
how to give someone else read permissions to a single page and not to 
the whole account? Or would the universal link be truly universal (i.e. 
not ACL-protected at all)? Arguably it is easier for you to send the 
page to your accountant by email (send by value rather than send by 
reference).

If identity is confusing to geeks imagine how it would be to end-users 
if we started trying to give them every possible option. (but on the 
other hand, the pervasive concept of "permalink" shows that some people 
are innovating around issues of resource identity UI)

2. In this case I don't see the relevance of which of the two 
authorization regimes you use.

  Paul Prescod
